Observations
What does it do?

Takes a N-Triples file and makes its resources HTTP resolvable (Linked Data).
Installation

Make sure you have the ruby development libraries:
sudo apt-get install ruby1.8-dev
You also need the GNU C++ compiler
sudo apt-get install g++
Install Ruby openssl binding
supo apt-get install libopenssl-ruby
Install RubyGems
sudo apt-get install rubygems
You need to tell Ruby to use RubyGems
export RUBYOPT=rubygems
Install Trinity
sudo gem install trinity
If installation succeeded, the files will be located in /var/lib/gems/1.8/gems/trinity-0.0.1
Evaluation

Test 1

Load
http://pdb2rdf.appspot.com/1y26
(~35000 triples)
After more than 30min of CPU at 100% trinity had not yet started.
Test 2

Load the sample file from TRINITY_HOME/etc/localhost.nt (7 triples)
It works fine. One can resolve resource URIs (e.g.
http://localhost:3000/hello/alias
)
Observations

The functionality is similar to that of presto (
http://presto-owl.googlecode.com
).
Doesn't rewrite URIs.
Does not seem to use a persistence mechanism. It looks like it loads the entire RDF graph on memory (i.e. bad!)
Does not support content negociation:
wget --accept=appliation/rdf+xml
http://localhost:3000/hello/alias
returns a text/plain file in N-TRIPLES
speaker: SYSTEM
